vi  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Effective learning programs are key to organizational performance and productivity. The World Bank's annual learning budget clearly reflects the high priority that the Bank places on these programs in an effort to equip staff with the tools needed to meet the demands of its work programs. In FY03, for example, the World Bank budgeted $67 million for a comprehensive range of staff learning opportunities; in FY04 the Bank increased its learning budget to $69.5 million.
The Human Development Network's (HDN) Strategic Learning Center (SLC) provides professional and technical learning on Human Development (HD)-related topics to HD staff throughout the Bank. Each year HDN receives an allocation from the Learning Board of just over $2 million for investments in staff learning. This represents about eight percent of the overall annual HDN budget. In FY04 alone, HDN invested $2.7 million, or eight percent of the overall HDN FY04 budget in its formal learning program endorsed by the Learning Board.
Given the large budget that HDN allocates to its annual learning programs under the Learning Board's directives, the objective of this evaluation is to assess the overall effectiveness of HDN learning programs. The evaluation is comprised of three components: (a) a review of HDN staff learning programs; (b) an assessment of the effects of the HD Forum 2003; and (c) an assessment of the impact of the Public Expenditure Review courses. Considering the size and time frame of each component, the evaluation results are presented in three individual reports.
This report focuses on the first component ­ a review of HDN staff learning programs. The key evaluation question addressed is, "Is the HDN learning program doing the right thing, in terms of the level of alignment with the objectives of the HD Network and fulfillment of the HD staff learning needs"? The answer to this question was obtained by examining the following four secondary evaluation questions:
(1) Did HDN learning programs enhance staff competency?
(2) How well are HDN learning programs aligned with HDN business objectives?
(3) What is the level of HD staff learning participation?
(4) How effective are HDN learning programs?
The evaluation utilized a combination of quantitative and qualitative approaches to address the above questions, including:
· Three focus group discussions with 12 HD managers about their expectations and satisfaction with the HDN staff learning programs;
vii  · A mapping exercise assessing the level of alignment of general HD staff learning needs with the HDN FY04 staff Learning Plan (LP) and program; · A descriptive analysis of HD staff participation over the past 19 months; and
· An online survey taken by over 300 HD staff regarding their expectations, experiences, and the effect of the learning programs on work performance.
CONCLUSIONS
The primary conclusions of this evaluation are that the HDN learning program largely meets HD staff learning needs and has produced some positive impact. However, the program is not closely aligned with HDN business objectives. The impact could be greater if the HDN learning program were designed in a more demand-driven fashion and if it were to provide cutting-edge technical training and make additional efforts to reach older, more experienced specialists and country office staff. These conclusions are supported by the following key findings:
HDN learning programs have adequately addressed staff learning needs and enhanced staff competency.
Managers expressed satisfaction with the quality and content of HDN learning programs and concluded that the programs have addressed, specifically, staff technical and operational competency. However, managers felt that staff needs to continue to update their technical training, sector-specific training, and operational training. Moreover, the LPs are closely aligned with managerial expectations and clearly address staff learning needs.
HDN learning programs are only partially aligned with the HDN business objectives.
According to HD managers interviewed, all of the Priority Areas listed in the HDN FY04 LP are in alignment with the overall HDN objectives in someway. However, out of the four Priority Areas agreed upon, most managers noted that Priority Areas #1 and #3 (Integrating HD into multi-sectoral and programmatic lending activities and Following up on the World Development Report [WDR] on service delivery) aligned most strongly with their work plan. A large share of the managers did not feel that Priority Areas #2 and #4 (Continuing to pay close attention to issues of portfolio quality and Improving momentum toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals) were addressed as efficiently.
Most HD staff adequately utilized the learning opportunities available to them.
The analysis of HR data reveals that over 70 percent of HD staff participated at some level in the learning programs during FY03 and FY04. On average, most HD staff attended between three and four learning events for a total of approximately six days. Professional and technical learning are the dominant learning events attended by HD staff
viii  and account for more than 40 percent of total learning event experiences. Moreover, the analysis shows that Headquarter (HQ) staff attended more learning activities than staff in country offices1, and that older staff, staff with more years of Bank service, and staff at higher grade levels participated in very few learning events.
The perceived effectiveness, utilization, and impact of HDN learning programs are relatively high. · The perceived quality and effectiveness of HDN learning activities is relatively high, especially in terms of networking and knowledge sharing. · The Professional Development Grant (PDG) was rated as the most effective of learning delivery modes, while the least effective delivery modes, according to the respondents, are E-Learning and B-Span, which were rated below the mid-point. · Knowledge and concepts are more highly exercised than specific skills and techniques acquired in the HDN learning activities. · The impact of the HDN learning events was almost exclusively evident in raising awareness and understanding of the HDN business as opposed to tangibly affecting the objectives of the Network themselves. · The appropriate type of learning (relevant to work) and the quality and effectiveness of that learning are more important than the frequency of learning participation in influencing impact.
RECOMMENDATIONS
Drawing from the key findings and gaps identified in this study, the evaluation offers the following recommendations to the HDN staff learning program:
(1) Equip staff with more applicable tools and skills;
(2) Design learning programs that integrate behavioral components (communication, interpersonal and leadership) with HD operational and technical components;
(3) Make the learning more relevant and applicable to staff's daily work by providing more demand-driven, time-sensitive, and cutting-edge learning events;
(4) Improve the design of sessions to increase team-based, peer, client and multi- sectoral learning and informal networking;
(5) Select and utilize the most welcome and effective of delivery modes, such as Professional Development Grants (PDGs);
1Nonetheless, country office staff, as compared to HQ staff, participate in a slightly greater number of learning days per year.
ix  (6) Explore ways to increase the level of participation of older, more experienced staff and under-privileged learners; and
(7) Explore ways to make technical learning more readily available to country office staff.

1.1 Effective learning programs are key to organizational performance and productivity. The World Bank's annual learning budget clearly reflects the high priority that the Bank places on continuous learning and in equipping its staff effectively to meet the demands of its work program.
CONTEXT
1.2 The Human Development Network (HDN) is also committed to helping staff meet the demands of its work program and to strengthening the contribution of Human Development (HD) staff to the overall business of the Bank. The HDN Strategic Learning Center (SLC) provides professional and technical learning on HD-related topics to HD staff throughout the Bank. HDN learning programs account for nearly four percent ($2 million) of the Learning Board's program budget and will provide 40 percent of all professional and technical learning in FY04. The $2 million represents about eight percent of the overall HDN budget.2 While HDN allocates the bulk of its learning budget to the preparation and delivery of formal HD learning events such as Bank Operations and professional and technical, Information and Technology (IT), and HR-related learning events, it also provides other staff learning opportunities, such as knowledge fairs, Brown Bag Lunches (BBLs), and Professional Development Grants (PDGs), which tailor learning opportunities to individual staff needs. In addition to formal courses, HDN spends around ten percent of its learning budget to host a bi-annual conference- style forum or "Sector Week," around which it concentrates a high volume of its class- based learning events.
1.3 As part of its FY04 work program agreement with the Learning Board, the World Bank Institute Evaluation Group (IEG) conducted an evaluation of the HDN learning programs. Given the large budget the HDN allocates to its annual learning programs under the Learning Board's directives, the objective of the evaluation is to assess the effectiveness of overall HDN learning programs.
1.4 This evaluation was designed in consultation with the HDN learning group to be comprised of three separate components: (a) a review of the HDN staff learning program; (b) an assessment of the effects of the HD Forum 2003 on participating staff; and (c) an assessment of the impact of the Public Expenditure Review courses. Considering the size and timeframe of each component, the evaluation results of each component are presented in three individual reports.
2In fact, HDN invests much more in staff learning. For example, the many Quality Enhancement Reviews (QERs) conducted by the HD-Hub often amounts to staff learning at its best--team-based action learning. Yet the considerable budget going into QERs is not formally considered part of the staff-learning budget. Many other services of the Hub also entail significant staff-learning components, but are generally classified in other ways.

The evaluation question stated above is examined from both supply and demand perspectives. On the supply side, the evaluation addresses whether or not the HDN learning programs planned reflect HDN business objectives and adequately address staff needs. On the demand side, the evaluation attempts to determine the effectiveness and impact of the HDN learning program on HD staff and on the HDN business objectives. (1) Did HDN learning programs enhance staff competency?
(2) How well are HDN learning programs aligned with HDN business objectives?

1.8 Four evaluation activities were carried out during the evaluation phase to address above evaluation questions including:
(1) Focus groups and individual interviews with HD managers and senior staff.
· The purpose of this activity was to collect feedback regarding the alignment of HDN learning programs with HDN business objectives and to determine whether or not the learning is meeting the needs of the staff.
(2) A desk review of the HDN learning activities offered in FY03­04. · The objective of this exercise was to assess how well the HDN learning programs offered reflect the objectives of the HDN work program in terms of improving HD staff key competencies.

LIMITATIONS
1.10 As with any evaluation, this study is not without its limitations. As a result, readers are encouraged to exercise caution in interpreting the findings herein for the following reasons:
1.11 The evaluation attempts to distinguish between HD staff learning demand and supply. HD staff demands are placed not only on the HDN learning program, but also on Human Resources (HR) behavioral types and Operations learning programs. In addition, the HDN learning programs supply HD focused learning, but not exclusively to HD staff. In other words, the fact that HDN learning programs supplied throughout FY03­04 are not targeted exclusively to HD staff must be taken into consideration when attempting to determine the overall relationship between demand and supply.
3The HD Anchor was in the spring of 2004 renamed to the HD-Hub. To differentiate between learning events organized by regional HD sector units and those organized by the HDN learning program, we use the term "HD-Hub learning " to refer the HDN learning program in the staff survey. Thus, both terms, HD- Hub learning and HDN learning, are used simultaneously and interchangeably in this report.
3  1.12 Further, the participant reports presented in the results section of the mapping exercise should not be taken as exact, but rather as approximate indicators of the alignment between the learning demand and the supply of learning by the HDN learning program for two reasons. First, the data resulting from the mapping exercise is incomplete. Second, because HDN does not categorize its offerings into separate areas or groups, the mapping results were subjective.

4  2. ALIGNMENT OF HDN LEARNING PROGRAMS WITH HDN OBJECTIVES: ACCORDING TO MANAGERS
2.1 This chapter presents the evaluation results concerning the alignment of HDN learning programs with HDN business objectives (work program). The main source of this assessment is information collected from HD manager focus groups and interviews.
METHODS AND INSTRUMENT
2.2 All HD managers received an email from the manager of the IEG inviting them to participate in focus groups and individual interviews to share their views on the effectiveness of the HDN learning program. A total of 12 HD managers agreed to participate. Three focus groups and three individual interviews lasting approximately two hours were conducted.
2.3 These 12 managers were evenly spread across regions and HD sectors. Each of the six regions was represented by at least one manager, while two HD managers attended from the Human Development Network Vice Presidential Unit (HDNVPU) and the World Bank Institute Human Development (WBIHD). The managers involved had no less than ten years total Bank experience, though the levels of managerial experience ranged from one to 11 years in the following categories: manager, sector manager, senior adviser, and country or sector director.
2.4 A questionnaire (see Annex 1) comprised of four broad, open-ended questions was developed to guide the focus group discussions and individual interviews. Additionally, managers were provided with a copy of the HDN FY04 LP. The focus groups and interviews explore the following questions:
(1) What are the key competencies required for working in HD?
(2) How satisfied are HD managers that the current HDN learning programs have:
· addressed the key competencies required for staff to fulfill the requirements of the HDN work program?
· met the perceived individual learning needs of HD staff?
(3) What do managers expect from the HDN learning programs?
(4) How well are HDN learning programs aligned withHDN business objectives?

HD specific competencies
2.7 HD specific competencies consist of: (1) a core set of HD sector-specific competencies, (2) a set of cross-sectoral or multi-sectoral competencies, and (3) basic operational competencies.
HD sector specific/technical competencies
2.8 The competency most frequently mentioned as necessary for functioning effectively in HD sectors was a set of HD sector-specific competencies. Almost all of the 12 managers interviewed (N = 11) felt that in order for staff to function effectively in the HD Network, they needed to have, in the words of one the managers, "very narrow
6  technical HD sector-specific competencies, depending on which sector specific issues they are working on".
2.9 Some managers felt that sector-specific competencies alone were not enough to function effectively in HD. In their view, it is essential for staff to have a mix of sector- specific and technical competencies. The most frequently named technical competency was pure economics.
"...I think one of the problems that we face in our multi-sectoral lending is that it is dominated by our macro economists, and in order to be credible, quite often it doesn't mean that there is a 100 percent correlation, but a strong correlation that an economist is better able to do that. ...I think you need a mix of the two [economics and sectoral expertise]."
2.10 Most managers, however, felt that although pure economists are useful to the Network, possessing "very narrow sector-specific technical competencies" related to Health, Nutrition and Population (HNP), Social Protection (SP) and Education is far more essential for HD staff. "Staff", according to one manger, "must be technically knowledgeable about their area. If they are in Education, they must understand education, if they are in Health, also health. ...They need to know what they are talking about when they go to a minister of health or minister of education."
Multi-sectoral/integrated competencies
2.11 The competency mentioned by managers second-most frequently as critical to functioning effectively within HD was multi-sectoral or integrated competency. Ten managers felt that, in addition to having core HD sector-specific technical competencies, staff should be able to work effectively multi-sectorally. Working multi-sectorally or integratively means that HD staff need to be familiar with the work of their colleagues as well as with the work conducted by sectors outside of HD. "[HD needs] people who work on multi-sectoral programs which, a lot of the times happens to be expenditures as it relates to outcomes in our sector, as opposed to being pure specialist type of things. I think you need an economist that's literate in the field and a specialist who is literate as an economist. So you need people who can build bridges and integrate ideas. You need people who can walk on both feet," according to one Africa Region (AFR) senior sector manager.
2.12 When considering how HDN can effectively accomplish the objectives articulated in its FY04 LP, particularly Priority Area # 1, "Integrating HD into Multi-Sectoral and Programmatic Lending Activities", and Priority Area # 3, "Following up on the WDR on Service Delivery", most managers felt that HD staff need to be able to work cross- sectorally. Essentially, HDN needs not only staff literate in the field of economics, but also staff possessing key HD sector-specific competencies in order to effectively integrate narrow, sector-specific technical skills with skills outside of their own areas of expertise and to broaden Network-wide awareness.
7  2.13 Overall, HD managers feel that HD staff need to broaden the scope of their understanding of the HD Network to include the work done by their colleagues not only in HD, but also in other sectors outside of the HD. In that way, HD staff will be able to lead multi-sectoral lending dialogues and promote HD products. More specifically, according to one manager, "they need to be open-minded to deal with multi-sectoral programmatic lending". Open-mindedness, according to another manager, requires that HD staff are willing to work with colleagues in other sectors so as to "have an understanding of the context of their specialty, and how it links with HD". Staff also need to "...understand the Sector, what are the key players in the Sector so that they can have an understanding and have an effective dialogue...for the non-economist they need to have enough of an understanding of the macro picture, then there are things that depend on the Sector, like health...good practices, etc." More importantly, working multi-sectorally requires that HD staff learn "how you relate to clients, how you really integrate your sector with a country driven agenda," says another manager.
Operational competencies
2.14 Six managers interviewed cited operational competencies as key to working within the HD Network. Though some managers differentiated between core operational competencies and generic operational competencies, the following basic operational competencies necessary for all new staff are agreed upon:
· Internal Bank procedures; · Budget;
· Portfolio management; · Basic safeguards;
· Basic tool kits.
2.15 Managers also identified the following more advanced operational competencies, which have built in technical and multi-sectoral components: · Public Expenditure Reviews (PER);
· Poverty Reduction Strategy Papers (PRSP); and · Poverty Reduction Strategy Credits (PRSC).
New and cutting-edge skills competencies: continuous learning
2.16 In addition to the core technical and sector competencies noted above, six of the HD managers interviewed also considered it crucial that HD staff be life-long or continuous learners. Being a lifelong learner, according to the managers interviewed, requires that HD staff expand their knowledge base so as to stay on the cutting-edge of their technical sector-specific specialties.
2.17 Continuous learning requires a certain amount of open-mindedness and humility on the part of the HD staff. They need to be willing to admit that they lack certain
8  information and to be open to learning from others. "...You know what you don't know," says one manager, "[you should be] humble enough to bring in other people," says another. "[You should]...open your mind to other things and other ways of doing things. It really helps them [new staff] gain competence and in getting a sense of themselves," suggests a third manager.
2.18 Managers recommended that staff seek out new and cutting-edge knowledge by looking to experienced peers, managers and clients for mentoring and coaching outside the bank.
General non-HD specific competencies
2.19 Managers also suggest that HD staff develop general non-HD specific competencies in order to be at their most effective both within and outside HD. Most managers (N = 9) felt that HD staff needed to complement their narrow set of technical/sector-specific competencies with general non-sector related competencies. Table 2 shows the four general non-HD competencies that managers considered crucial for effectiveness. The top-most competencies mentioned are: · Team building;
· General leadership; and · Behavioral
Team building competencies
2.20 Eight managers considered team building as the most crucial of the non-technical skill competencies necessary for working effectively in HD. Network managers felt that since one of the key Priority Areas of the HDN FY04 LP is integrating HD into multi- sectoral and programmatic lending, it is important that HD staff be able to relate to one another, as well as to clients and partners. More importantly, staff need to be active in a multi-sectoral team environment. In order for this to happen, some managers pointed out, staff need to be "humble enough" to admit to limitations and willing to learn from peers, supervisors, and clients. Learning from each other means developing good listening skills, which, in the managers' views, is crucial for working together in multi-sectoral teams. The following comments from one sector manager echo the sentiments of his colleagues:
"One skill that is becoming very important in the Bank is interpersonal skills, because of the evolving nature of our work, where we work in multi-sectoral teams, multi-skill teams, etc., it is very important that one is able to function in that kind of environment because you are not working alone you are working together with others. ...So, because our task managers or members of our teams work in multi-sectoral teams and multi-sector dimensional teams, because of these multi-sectoral teams, it is very crucial that they have good interpersonal skills."
9  "And the interpersonal skills go way beyond just working with other Bank staff. Also, how do they deal with the clients. Because if they don't know how to deal with the clients, I have seen very many staff, in other words, staff who have very good technical skills, very strong Bank operational skills, fall flat because their interpersonal skills in teams were very bad. Their interpersonal skills with the clients were very bad. So, these skills, some of them, are invisible but they are very crucial."
2.21 Apart from good listening skills, which was perceived as "the real shortfall of staff", another important aspect of team building, in managers' views, is the ability to be able to communicate effectively with team members. Effective communication means not only good listening skills, but also the ability to: · write well;
· lead dialogues with colleagues and clients; · be well versed on the effectiveness of the HD product issues discussed in those dialogues; and · demonstrate competency when doing so, instead of adopting a "bleeding hearts approach".
2.22 All managers observed that informal networking at HD Fora was one of the most effective means by which HD staff could strengthen relationships and build stronger multi-sectoral teams. Informal networking is also viewed as a good vehicle for team- based and client learning. Informal networking is considered so valuable for building stronger teams that managers confirmed that more than half of their learning budget was allocated to bringing staff from country offices to HQ and other country offices so that they could network with both their counterparts and other colleagues. The following extracts from one of the managers focus groups suggest the value managers ascribe to informal networking as it relates to team building:
"We spent more than 50 percent of the budget this year [FY04] on the HD Week and the Pre HD Week, Learning Week. And we brought everybody from the field offices for two weeks here. So that was partly to give them exposure. ...Two thirds of our staff are in the country office. So for us, it is important to bring them here and to give them exposure, to see what's going on here in Headquarters. So, I think that is the major motivation. SUMMARY
2.53 Overall, managers who attended the focus groups indicated that in order for HD staff to work effectively within and outside of the HD Network, the following three key HD-specific competencies are pivotal: · Core competencies, both technical and HD-sector specific;
· Multi-sectoral competencies; and · Operational competencies.
2.54 In addition to these competencies, managers felt that HD staff needs to focus on continuous learning. As adult learners, they need to: 1) fully embrace the concept of learning, and 2) seek out non-traditional ways of learning. Managers suggested peer learning, mentoring and coaching from experienced colleagues and managers, and client learning as effective modes of continuous learning.
19  2.55 Managers expressed satisfaction with the quality and content of the technical and operational learning that HDN currently provides. However, managers felt that staff need to keep their technical training, sector specific learning and operational learning consistent and current. Despite overall satisfaction with the quality of HD-provided technical training, some managers felt that the following aspects of the program could be improved: · Focus (integrated or multi-sectoral versus compartmentalized);
· Content (tailored/demand driven versus generic/supply driven); and · Organization and scheduling.
2.56 Managers considered it important that the HDN learning program continues not only to provide staff with technical and HD sector-specific training, but also to integrate the learning to include other sectors. Integrated learning would make staff aware of and impart substantive input to the work of their colleagues in other sectors within HD. It would also prepare staff to work multi-sectorally with Networks outside of HD. Managers observed that the HD staff are not yet able to make substantive contributions outside of their own sectors, as compared to staff from other Networks such as PREM.
2.57 Managers also stressed that it is crucial for all HDN learning to be tailored to the specific needs of staff. All managers strongly suggested that learning should be multi- sectorally focused; some suggested that learning not only be customized, but also cutting- edge in content. Cutting-edge knowledge is presumed to enhance good practices and introduce new lending instruments. It will also raise staff's awareness and influence their perception. Overall, managers expect the learning program to provide current, relevant, and demand-driven technical, operational and leadership training. Managers agreed that demand-driven learning is more relevant to staff needs and more likely to have a greater impact on work performance and effectiveness than supply-driven training.
2.58 Managers agreed that the four Priority Areas listed in the FY04 LP are only in partial alignment with the HDN work program. Priority Area #1, Integrating HD into multi-sectoral and programmatic lending activities and Priority Area #3, Following up on the WDR on service delivery met their expectations, while Priority Areas #2, Continuing to pay close attention to issues of portfolio quality and #4, Increasing momentum toward achieving the MDGs, although present in the LP, are not in complete accordance with manager expectations.

SUMMARY
3.26 This chapter presents the evaluation results of the alignment of the HDN FY04 LP with the HD manager assessments and the alignment of the HDN LP with HD staff learning needs. In essence, the results show:
Areas where alignment is good
3.27 Generally, the HDN LP and the learning offerings in FY04 seem to be well aligned with the key competencies and learning needs that HD managers listed as top- most priority. The main knowledge and skills that managers designated of highest need are: sector-specific/technical, operational and multi-sectoral/integrative. These categories are also of top priority to the LP and were addressed in the majority of learning events attended by staff.
3.28 The fourth area that managers stated as important to staff learning is team building. A great number of team building events take place during the bi-annual Forum in the form of informal networking. Team building is the main focus in the Foundations of Team Leadership Module. The only weakness of this event is that it

3.29 The fifth area of importance to managers regarding staff learning encompasses behavioral, communication and leadership skills. SUMMARY
4.30 This chapter presents the results of the analysis of HD staff learning participation over the past 19 months (FY03­04). Considering the entirety of the data, most analyses performed are based on FY03 staff learning records and on all learning events that staff reported.
4.31 The average level of staff learning participation in the HD Network is satisfactory. The HR data results reveal that over 70 percent of HD staff participated in some learning activities during the study period. Of the 150 HD staff who were inactive in learning during FY03, only a small portion did not engage in any learning activities at all over the entire two and half years. The majority of the non-active learning staff in FY03 was composed of senior staff stationed in HQ. Most HD staff attended between three and four learning events lasting around six days.
4.32 According to the survey, the majority of HD staff (excluding non-active learning staff) reported that they attended an average of 2.02 HDN activities lasting one day or longer in FY03, while the number activities attended lasting less than one day was 3.36 on average. Compared to the results from the two data sources, these figures are not far off considering that the HR learning records are likely incomplete--especially for shorter learning activities, such as BBLs.
4.33 Highly experienced and country office staff attended fewer learning events, but the type of learning attended by staff is consistent with demands. The influence of geographical location and, to a lesser extent, grade level on learning participation is substantial. Staff stationed in HQ and GE-GF staff were more likely to be active, high- intensity learners. In terms of learning fields engaged in by the HD staff, professional and technical topics were the most popular field for HD staff, accounting for more than 40 percent of total learning, followed by HR related learning. Again, a clear difference
43  is evident between higher level and lower level staff and between HQ and country office staff in choosing learning events to attend. Country office staff, less experienced, and lower level HD staff engaged in more Bank Operations learning. The choices made by the HD staff, on the one hand, reflect the importance of these learning events in helping them to conduct the Bank's business at different stages of their Bank experience. On the other hand, it may reflect that learning events available are not always physically accessible and do not meet the learning needs of all target groups.
4.34 Technical learning for country office staff could be improved by delivering cutting-edge BBLs in another form to country office staff. A lack of local learning opportunities (supply) or lack of capacity to access centralized/external learning opportunities may make it difficult for HD staff stationed outside of HQ to participate in more professional and technical learning activities. As mentioned earlier, BBLs are one of the most popular professional and technical learning activities for HQ HD staff. Each year, more than 200 BBLs are held in HQ, constituting a large share of the HDN staff learning program. As BBLs are shorter, often offered during the lunchtime, and usually revolve around cutting-edge professional and technical issues, they are a unique learning mechanism for HQ staff.
4.35 Senior staff, staff over the age of 50, and staff with a substantial number of years of Bank experience are low-intensity learners, especially in terms of their learning days. It is understandable that staff who have been with the Bank for a number of years may have more highly developed skills than less experienced staff. Regardless, it is necessary for all staff to stay up to date and face new challenges. BBLs are one effective way to share new and cutting-edge professional topics with more experienced staff, but they are not necessarily the most efficient format for teaching updated Bank Operations and new technology. Most Operations related learning events and IT learning events are designed as formal courses that take place in a classroom or laboratory setting. As most of these staff members are TTLs and may be relied upon heavily to deliver services, they may find it harder to engage in some learning events, particularly those with a longer duration. Clearly, determining how best to design a learning event that is accessible to higher-level staff both physically and functionally is a strategic issue for the HDN learning program. The next chapter will investigate the causes behind low intensity learning participation, and assesses the feasibility of HDN learning for country office staff.

5.1 This chapter focuses on the effectiveness, utilization and impact of the learning activities offered by the HDN learning program. It also attempts to explain further some of the findings presented in the previous chapter. Summarily, this chapter addresses the following evaluation questions:

Analysis
5.7 In addition to providing descriptive explanations of the different components of the analysis, we used regression techniques to assess the relationship between learning participation and the effectiveness, utilization, and impact of the learning events. We evaluated these relationships statistically in a four-step analytical framework, depicted in Figure 12.
5.8 The framework we used was designed under the assumption that the level of participation is determined by a bundle of exogenous demographic characteristics (Stage 1 in Figure 12). For example, we assume that staff with ILPs are more likely to participate in learning events than staff without ILPs. Also, because staff that are stationed at HQ have better access to learning events than staff stationed in country offices, we presume that these HQ staff may participate more frequently than country office staff. Furthermore, we presume that job category, grade level and experience may affect the levels of participation, but we do not make any predetermined expectations regarding utilization and impact.
5.9 Secondly, for those staff who attended learning in FY03 (level of participation from stage 1>0) perceived effectiveness/usefulness of the learning is determined by the level of participation and the bundle of demographics (Stage 2). We hypothesize that perceived effectiveness/usefulness of learning events increases with the level of participation in HDN learning.
5.10 Thirdly, we assume that the degree to which participants utilize the knowledge and skills taught in the learning events depends on how effective/useful staff rated the learning, the influence of the bundle of demographic factors, and any possible facilitators/barriers (Stage 3). However, we believe that the level of participation may not affect utilization since, even if participation is very low (e.g. one activity per year), participants can still exercise the learning obtained.

5.47 The survey asked staff to list up to three topics or learning activities that they wish the HDN learning programs will offer in the future. 5.48 Survey respondents also provided opinions and suggestions for the HDN learning programs in general. They also felt strongly about including clients in the learning events. 64  6. CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
6.1 This report presents the results of a review of the HDN learning program. The overarching evaluation question is whether the HDN learning program is doing the right thing, in terms of the level of alignment with the objectives of the HD Network and fulfillment of HD staff learning needs.
6.2 Four evaluation activities were carried out during the evaluation phase to address various sub-evaluation questions.
CONCLUSIONS
6.3 The primary conclusions of this evaluation are that the HDN learning program largely meets HD staff learning needs and has produced some positive impact. However, the program is not closely aligned with HDN business objectives. The impact can be greater if the HDN learning program were designed in a more demand-driven fashion and if it were to provide cutting-edge technical training and make additional efforts to reach older, more experienced specialists and country office staff. These conclusions are supported by the following key findings:
HDN learning programs have adequately addressed staff learning needs and improved staff competencies.
6.4 According to HD managers, in order for HD staff to work effectively within and outside of the HD, they need three key HD-specific competencies and three general non- sector related competencies. These are: · Sector-specific;
· Multi-sectoral competencies; · Operational;
· Team building; · General leadership; and
· Behavioral.
6.5 Managers believe that multi-sectoral and operational training, and team building and leadership learning are of great need.
6.6 Managers expressed satisfaction with the quality and content of HDN learning programs in addressing staff technical and operational competencies. However, managers felt that staff need to continue to update their technical training, sector-specific training, and operational training.
65  6.7 The proven alignment of the LP and learning offered by the Network with what managers believe to be the most important areas for the HDN learning program to focus on supports the finding that the HDN learning program is addressing staff learning needs sufficiently.
6.8 However, both the manager focus groups and the desk review suggest several areas need improvement to ensure that all staff are equally included in the learning agenda. For example, the current learning program could incorporate into its design activities country office staff, adult learning and multi-sectoral learning. Also, incorporating HR related learning into traditional HD specific learning events would improve team learning, communication, and cooperation within HD and would likely enhance the applicabilityof the HD specific learning.
HDN learning programs are partially aligned with the HDN business objectives.
6.9 According to the managers, all of the Priority Areas listed in the HDN FY04 LP are aligned with the HDN work program in some way or another. However, of the four Priority Areas established, most managers felt alignment was strongest between Priority Areas #1 and #3 (Integrating HD into multi-sectoral and programmatic lending activities and Following up on the WDR on service delivery) and their work plans. A large share of the managers did not consider Priority Areas #2 and #4 (Continuing to pay close attention to issues of portfolio quality and Improving momentum toward achieving the MDGs) to be closely aligned with their work program. To most managers, these two issues are ongoing concepts, not concrete activities; thus it is difficult to determine their alignment with the work program.
Most HD staff adequately utilized the learning opportunities available to them.
6.10 The analysis of HR data reveals that over 70 percent of HD staff participated in some learning during the study period. On average, most HD staff attended between three and four learning events lasting around six days. In line with the competencies that HD managers believe that their staff need, professional and technical learning is the dominating type of learning attended by HD staff, accounting for more than 40 percent of total learning. Of the 150 HD staff who were inactive in learning during FY03, only a small portion of staff did not engage in any learning in the entire two and half years covered by the study. The majority of non-active learning staff in FY03 are senior staff stationed at HQ. Moreover, the analysis identifies that HQ staff attended more learning activities than staff in country offices, and older staff, staff with more years of Bank service, and staff higher grade levels participated in very few learning events.
6.11 The staff survey denotes lack of time, money and other resources as the main reasons for low-intensity participation in HDN learning events. This is especially evident for country office staff, who have very limited opportunities to attend learning events at HQ, particularly BBLs. The complete inaccessibility of BBLs to country office staff is of great concern since these events are an important channel for professional, technical and cutting-edge learning and knowledge sharing.
66  The level of perceived effectiveness, utilization, and impact of HDN programs is relatively high.
Perceived quality and effectiveness of HDN learning activities is relatively high
6.12 Staff gave "Providing opportunities for networking and knowledge sharing" the highest rating of all the event aspects at 4.05 on a scale of one to five, with five representing the most desirable learning event aspect. The lowest-rated learning aspect was "Helping you know the resources to call on to do things differently".
PDG was considered as the most effective learning delivery mode
6.13 Staff rated the Professional Development Grant Program (PDG) as the most effective of all HDN learning program delivery modes (mean = 4.37 on a scale of one to five). Classroom sessions, conferences, team learning and informal learning such as brown-bag lunches were rated as equally effective, at ratings ranging from 3.63 to 3.97. The least-effective delivery modes according to the respondents were E-Learning (mean = 2.86) and B-Span (mean = 2.91), which rated below the mid-point.
Use of knowledge and concepts acquired in the HDN learning activities is relatively high
6.14 The reported average use of knowledge and concepts is 3.78 on a scale of one to five. Staff find it more difficult to make use of specific skills and techniques (mean = 3.49 on the same scale). The factors that facilitate use are relevance of the content of the learning to the work of the participant and support from managers and peers. Lack of time, money, and staff resources are the main barriers to HDN learning utilization.
HDN learning programs had some positive impact
6.15 The impact of the HDN learning events is almost exclusively focused on awareness raising and building understanding of the HDN business, rather than directly affecting the objectives of the Network. Events that teach new and improve existing knowledge and skills are the ones with the highest impact ratings.
Relationship between learning participation and effectiveness, utilization and impact
6.16 What is evident from the 4-step regression analysis is that there is no statistically significant relationship between levels of participation (e.g. the number of days per year staff spend on HD learning) and perceived effectiveness, utilization and impact. This suggests that the levels of learning participation are really not a matter in producing impacts. What seems the most important is the relevance of the learning, as well as the quality thereof.
RECOMMENDATIONS
6.17 Drawing on the key findings and gaps identified by this evaluation, we offer the following recommendations to improve the HDN learning programs:
67  (1) Equip staff with more applicable tools and skills;
(2) Design learning programs that integrate behavioral components (communication, interpersonal and leadership) with HD operational and technical components;
(3) Make the learning more relevant and applicable to staff work objectives by providing more demand-driven, just-in-time, and cutting-edge training;
(4) Improve the design of sessions to increase team-based, peer, client and multi- sectoral learning and informal networking;
(5) Select and utilize the most welcome and effective delivery modes, such as PDGs, to deliver the learning programs;
(6) Explore ways to increase the level of participation of older, more experienced staff and under-privileged learners; and
(7) Explore ways to make technical learning more readily available to country office staff.
Equip staff with more applicable tools and skills.
6.18 The HDN learning program should focus on equipping staff with more applicable tools and skills if the Network wants to increase the impact of staff learning and improve performance and quality of work. The current learning offered by the Network is mainly raises awareness. This type of learning is non-specific and does not often translate into results on the overall business performance level.
Design learning programs that integrate behavioral components (communication, interpersonal and leadership) with HD operational and technical components.
6.19 The HDN learning program could benefit from incorporating behavioral learning. HD managers specifically stated that the skills staff need to work efficiently within the HD are in the areas of behavioral, communication and team leadership training. As these types of skills fall outside of core HD training, the learning program does not include such learning events. However, because managers value these interpersonal skills very highly, the HDN learning program may want to include them in their LP. Incorporating some behavioral components into the HDN LP would equip staff with both technical knowledge and the behavioral skills necessary to improve efficiency.
Make the learning more relevant and applicable to staff daily by providing more demand-driven, just-in-time, and cutting-edge training.
6.20 Given that even low-level learning participation may still generate positive outcomes and impacts, the learning program should focus on increasing the effectiveness, relevance, and applicability of staff learning. For instance, making the learning demand driven and just-in-time is something that managers emphasize as important both in
68  reaching low-intensity learners and improving the existing learning offerings. One suggestion for improvement of the HDN learning program is to offer more team building, behavioral, general leadership, and communications learning especially targeted to HD staff.
Improve the design of sessions to increase team based, peer, client and multi- sectoral learning and informal networking.
6.21 To be more effective, HDN could shift from the current pedagogical, classroom- delivery mode to an andragogical (adult learning) delivery mode, as this mode of design and delivery has been found to be more effective with adult learners.
Select and utilize the most welcome and effective delivery modes, such as PDGs, to deliver the learning programs.
6.22 To enhance staff learning and to ensure the best outcome of the learning programs, HDN should carefully select and utilize the most welcome and effective delivery modes suggested by HD staff, such as PDGs, to deliver the learning programs.
Explore ways to increase the level of participation of older, more experienced staff and under-privileged learners.
6.23 Although most of the HDN learning program is well aligned with staff learning needs and the participation levels, quality and effectiveness of the events are up to standard, there are a few areas where the Network could improve its learning program to include under-privileged learners and facilitate the utilization and impact of the learning that HD staff attend. The HND learning program needs to ensure that this group of staff remain life-long learners, learn from each other, and stay on the cutting-edge of the knowledge frontier. For instance, HDN could improve the level of participation in learning by designing learning activities to attract older, senior, and more experienced staff. These staff have been found to be low intensity learners. Further investigation and expertise is required to understand the factors that contribute to successful adult learning, including how to motivate and inspire senior staff to attend more staff learning. In addition, non-traditional methods of learning need to be explored in order to better reach the senior staff. One recommendation is that HDN conduct learning needs assessments targeted to low intensity and non-learners.
Explore ways to make technical learning more readily available to country office staff.
6.24 Another under-privileged group of staff is staff that are stationed outside of HQ. Specifically, the HDN learning program needs to include country office staff in sector- specific/technical, and cutting-edge learning. Currently, BBLs make up a large part of the technical learning events offered, however, they are almost exclusively available to HQ staff. Country office staff have few opportunities to attend HQ-based learning events. This is an important challenge for the HD Network, keeping in mind that distance learning methods such as video conferencing, B-Span and E-Learning are rated the least effective of all HDN learning delivery modes. In order to increase the amount
69  of sector-specific and technical learning that country office staff receive, it is recommended that HDN explores ways of making BBLs more accessible to the country office staff. For instance, the HD Learning Days, which are especially important to country office staff, could be a venue for increased transmission of technical and cutting- edge skills to country office staff.

doc.repnme: Evaluation of the human development network staff learning programs
doc.abstracts: This report focuses on the first component - a review of HDN staff learning programs. The key evaluation question addressed is, is the HDN learning program doing the right thing, in terms of the level of alignment with the objectives of the HD Network and fulfillment of the HD staff learning needs? The answer to this question was obtained by examining the following four secondary evaluation questions: (1) Did HDN learning programs enhance staff competency? (2) How well are HDN learning programs aligned with HDN business objectives? (3) What is the level of HD staff learning participation? (4) How effective are HDN learning programs?
